name: Beshbarmak
history: Beshbarmak is a traditional Kazakh dish, often referred to as the national dish of Kazakhstan.
recipe: Boil the meat, prepare the dough, and serve together with onion broth.
instructions: Boil the meat until tender.
Prepare pasta dough and cut into thin slices.
Cook the pasta slices in the meat broth.
Serve the meat over pasta with onion broth.

name: Manty
history: Dumplings filled with minced meat and onions, steamed to perfection. Commonly served with sour cream or butter.
recipe: Fill dough with spiced meat, shape into dumplings, and steam.
instructions: Prepare dough and let it rest.
Roll dough into circles and fill with meat.
Fold into dumplings and steam until cooked.

name: Plov
history: Plov, or pilaf, is a beloved rice dish in Central Asia, often cooked with meat, carrots, and aromatic spices.
recipe: Cook onions, meat, and carrots together, add rice, spices, and water, then simmer until done.
instructions: Heat oil in a large pot and sauté onions until golden.
Add meat and cook until browned.
Stir in carrots and cook until softened.
Add rice, garlic, and spices, then pour in water.
Simmer on low heat until rice absorbs the water and is fully cooked.
Fluff the rice gently with a fork before serving.

name: Kazy
history: A traditional Kazakh sausage made from horse meat, often served during festive meals.
recipe: Season horse rib meat, stuff into natural casing, and boil or smoke.
instructions: Marinate rib meat with spices and garlic.
Stuff the casing with meat.
Cook by boiling or smoking until ready.

name: Baursak
history: Fried dough balls or discs, often enjoyed as a snack or dessert. They symbolize hospitality.
recipe: Prepare dough, let it rise, shape, and deep-fry until golden.
instructions: Mix ingredients and knead dough.
Let the dough rise, then cut into small pieces.
Deep-fry until puffed and golden.

name: Shashlik
history: Marinated meat skewers grilled over open flames, popular at social gatherings.
recipe: Marinate meat, thread onto skewers, and grill over charcoal.
instructions: Marinate meat with onions, vinegar, and spices.
Thread onto skewers.
Grill over hot coals until tender and charred.

name: Kymyz
history: Fermented mare’s milk, a refreshing and slightly alcoholic traditional drink.
recipe: Ferment mare’s milk for a tangy, fizzy drink.
instructions: Collect fresh mare’s milk.
Add a fermenting agent and let it rest.
Stir regularly and serve chilled.

name: Sirne
history: A traditional lamb stew prepared in a cauldron, often during outdoor events or celebrations.
recipe: Slow-cook lamb with potatoes and spices for a rich, hearty meal.
instructions: Sear lamb in a pot.
Add onions, potatoes, and spices.
Cover with water and simmer until tender.
Serve with fresh herbs.

name: Lagman
history: A noodle dish of Uyghur origin, popular in Kazakhstan. Lagman combines hand-pulled noodles with meat and vegetable stew.
recipe: Prepare noodles and serve with a spiced meat and vegetable sauce.
instructions: Cook noodles until tender.
Stir-fry meat with vegetables and spices.
Combine noodles with the sauce and serve.

name: Burme
history: A savory pastry filled with meat and onions, resembling a spiral. Often baked in tandyr ovens.
recipe: Roll dough with meat filling into a spiral and bake until golden.
instructions: Roll out dough thinly and layer with meat filling.
Roll into a spiral and seal.
Bake until crispy and golden.

name: Shubat
history: Fermented camel milk, a staple in southern Kazakhstan, prized for its refreshing and nutritious qualities.
recipe: Ferment camel milk for a tangy, slightly fizzy drink.
instructions: Collect fresh camel milk.
Mix with a fermenting agent and let rest.
Stir regularly and serve chilled.

name: Tandyr Nan
history: Traditional bread baked in a tandyr oven, known for its chewy texture and slightly smoky flavor.
recipe: Knead dough, shape into flat discs, and bake in a tandyr.
instructions: Mix dough ingredients and let it rise.
Shape dough into flat rounds.
Bake in a preheated tandyr oven until golden.

name: Samsa
history: Meat-filled pastries baked in a tandyr or oven, similar to samosas, enjoyed as snacks or meals.
recipe: Fill dough with seasoned meat, fold into triangles, and bake.
instructions: Roll out dough and cut into squares.
Fill with meat and seal edges.
Bake until golden brown.

name: Tushpara
history: Kazakh dumplings similar to pelmeni, often served in broth as a comforting meal.
recipe: Fill dough with meat, boil in broth, and serve hot.
instructions: Roll out dough and cut into circles.
Add meat filling, fold, and seal edges.
Cook dumplings in boiling broth and serve.

name: Orama Nan
history: A layered bread rolled with savory fillings, often enjoyed with tea.
recipe: Roll out dough, layer with onions and spices, roll into a log, and bake.
instructions: Roll out dough thinly.
Spread onion and spice mixture evenly.
Roll into a log, slice, and bake until golden.
